H0.text: what kind of government does brazil has. Parliamentary Democracy

H1.text: what kind of government does brazil has. Constitutional Monarchy

H2.text: what kind of government does brazil has. Presidential System

H3.text: what kind of government does brazil has. Federal republic

A4.text: Brazil is a federal presidential constitutional republic.

A5.text: The President is both the head of state and the head of government.

A6.text: The president is elected for a four-year term, with the possibility of re-election for a second successive term.

A7.text: Brazil's current constitution, enacted in 1988, defines it as a democratic federal republic.

A8.text: The president appoints the Ministers of State, who form the cabinet and assist in government.

A9.text: Brazil is a federation composed of 26 states, one federal district, and the 5,571 municipalities.

A11.text: Brazil adopted the presidential system in 1889 with Deodoro da Fonseca as its first president.

A12.text: A federal republic is a federation of states with a republic as a form of government.

A13.text: This more decentralized structure helps to explain the tendency for more populous countries to operate as federal republics.

A14.text: The president has significant lawmaking powers, exercised either by proposing laws to the National Congress or by using Medidas Provisórias (provisional measures), an instrument with the force of law that the president can enact in cases of urgency and necessity except to make changes to some areas of law.

A15.text: The presidential system was established in 1889, upon the proclamation of the republic in a military coup d'état against Emperor Pedro II.

A17.text: In 2015, more than 40% of prisoners in Brazil were provisional.
